course."}],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"CODE1110 - Computational Design Theory 1","description":"

'This course addresses architecture’s digital turn and introduces students to historical and contemporary discourses, theoretical concepts and ideas, and architectural projects that have engaged digital technologies and computational design thinking and methods from the late twentieth century onwards. Students will undertake verbal, visual, and written modes of analysis to develop knowledge and critically evaluate discourses and architectural projects relating to digital and computational design technologies. Students will employ a range of verbal and multimedia communication mediums and skills to demonstrate their knowledge and analysis.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"5a805557dba93850be4672f5f3961921","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assignment 1: Reflective Writing (Individual)","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"20","description":"

Based on the weekly theme and its required readings students are required to write a 250-300 word synopsis supported by independent research (references, images, diagrams, and a range of representations) and post to the CODE 1110

Moodle site. The writing must demonstrate that the weekly assigned articles have been

closely read and interpreted. This can be achieved by discussing, comparing, and referencing the key concepts and examples from each article and the inclusion and interpretation of key quotes. The writing must adopt the Harvard style in-text referencing system and correctly attribute concepts, ideas and quotes.

 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"52805557dba93850be4672f5f3961923","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"5a805557dba93850be4672f5f3961922","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"56805557dba93850be4672f5f3961928","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Online Exam: Moodle Quiz (Individual)","assessment_type":{"label":"Test","value":"test"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"20","description":"

Multiple choice questions based on material presented in lectures and tutorial readings. Maximum of x2 attempts

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"52805557dba93850be4672f5f3961923","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"56805557dba93850be4672f5f3961963","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assignment 3: Interview with an architect (Group)","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"30","description":"

This assignment takes inspiration from the format of the Greg Lynn show where Lynn interviews significant architectural figures who are engaged in computational design thinking and methods to realise their architectural projects. In student pairs, students will choose a significant figure from the computational design paradigm (as discussed in lectures and readings) and script and film a highly polished 5minute (minimum) interview. Student teams will need to thoroughly research their selected figure and become familiar with their design philosophy and key projects to script both sides of the interview. The interview should also demonstrate the computational designer / architect’s situated-ness/position within the wider computational design context. For example, the interviewer may pose questions to interviewee about their view/response to other buildings/projects and other significant figures that are similar or different. The recorded interview should be curated to also include (throw to with voice overs) images and diagrams of the interviewee’s projects, as well as diagrams and 3D digital models created by the students to demonstrate spatial/material/formal concepts, i.e. computational processes or constructability models, visualisations, fly-thru, as well as completed project images. (projects by the interviewee do not need to necessarily be built). The interview script, and the recorded interview, should demonstrate inventiveness, creativity, and critical reflection. It should be compelling as well as intellectual, and find ways to demonstrate the knowledge and interpretation of the computational design paradigm gained through the student’s own research as well as the lecture and course material delivered throughout the semester.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"52805557dba93850be4672f5f3961922","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"52805557dba93850be4672f5f3961923","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"5a805557dba93850be4672f5f3961922","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"5a805557dba93850be4672f5f3961923","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"9a805557dba93850be4672f5f396195d","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assignment 2: Discourse formations – Computational Design timelines (Individual)","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"30","description":"

This assignment employs Michel Foucault’s notion of a “discursive formation” to explore how the computational design paradigm has been constituted and articulated through certain images, concepts, texts, and practices. For Foucault (1972), a discursive formation concerns the way meanings are connected together across multiple texts or sources. In this way, discourse can be understood as “a coherent pattern of statements across a range of archives and sites” (Green quoted in Rose 2012, p.198). Select a project from an architect featured in the key course text The Archaeology if the Digital: Frank Gehry, Chuck Hoberman, Shoei Yoh (Lynn 2013). This project will act as the initial ‘protagonist’ from which to then research an additional 4 other projects (by the same or different architect/inventor/engineer) and construct a discursive formation in the shape of a graphic and textual ‘timeline’. The content of the timeline could address themes such as form, space, concept, goal, organisation (function, space, circulation, material process), typology, materiality, client/user. The timeline should construct a system of dispersion – i.e. logic of connecting the selected projects/concepts/themes. The timeline should question the ‘true’ meaning of the project, and challenge the preconceived linearity of time, past and future.

 

 

 

Peer critique from tutors.

The communication and visualisation course introduces students to the simulation, manipulation and visualisation of complex data information. Using a synthesis of technical and theoretical knowledge of design computing, students will apply skills in a text based programming language to inform their own design projects and professional work. Students will participate to weekly laboratory-based activities to experiment with and develop further their technical knowledge. The students performance will be evaluated with respect to their progressive work developed in preparation for or during the studio activities. Students will employ a range of verbal and multimedia communication skills to demonstrate their explorations and results.

course."}],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"CODE1210 - Computational Design Theory 2","description":"

'The Computational Design Theory II course builds on the foundational knowledge of CODE1110 – Computational Design Theory I, that introduced students to computational thinking and methods in the context of the architectural discipline and practice, to investigate historic and contemporary approaches to representing, conceptualising, and designing the built environment in relationship to digital culture and computing technologies. Students will develop and apply advanced critical thinking skills to analyse relationships between digital culture and the built environment and apply conceptual and theoretical ideas to interpret and explain their findings. This course explores and advances the ethical application of digital and computational technologies to inform the student’s own design practice.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"e7905d57dba93850be4672f5f396191f","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assignment 3: Publicity – Technology debates (Group 15% / Individual 20%)","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"35","description":"

This assignment develops critical thinking in the form of a group debate conducted in class. This activity will foster critical thinking skills by investigating arguments, engaging in research, gathering information, performing analysis, assessing arguments, questioning assumptions and demonstrating interpersonal skills. The purpose of critical thinking is to use questioning techniques to achieve understanding, evaluate view points, and solve problems. Each tutorial group will form opposing and affirmative teams to compete against each other. Debate teams and resource material will be organised in Week 10. Team sizes of no more than 4 people, no less than 3. Teams will be allocated a declarative statement and a side to support or oppose. The affirmative team will argue to support the resolution/declarative statement, while the negative team will be tasked with opposing it. Students will need to build a case for their allocated resolution and in doing so, try to prove or disprove the opposing side’s resolution through evidence, scholarly references, and argument. A debate is characterised by the method of persuasion. Compelling, engaging and persuasive communication is key to a successful debate.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"63905d57dba93850be4672f5f3961921","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"63905d57dba93850be4672f5f3961922","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"6b905d57dba93850be4672f5f3961921","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"3b905d57dba93850be4672f5f396192b","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assignment 2: The socio-digital life of small urban spaces (Group 15 % / Individual 20%)","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"35","description":"

TASK 1 & 2 OBSERVATIONS GROUPWORK (15%): TASK 1: VISUAL OBSERVATION In groups of no more than x3 students this assignment requires you to observe and record (photograph/film/reflect on your own experience) the ways people engage with digital technologies within an allocated public realm site in the City of Sydney (tutor to allocate sites). Using photographs or time-lapse video to spatially map the movements and intensities (densities) of people/objects/animals/technology engagement through the site to identify patterns and key behaviours. Develop a code system to analyse and describe your observations and explain their significance.

TASK 2: DIGITAL OBSERVATION – SOCIAL MEDIA DATA ANALYSIS Students are required to apply the skills learned in the social media data, network analysis, and content analysis workshop run in Week 3 to search and analyse social media data relevant to their public realm site:

• import data from social media platforms such as Twitter and Facebook

• conduct data processing, analysis, and visualisation, as well as content mining

• interpret the results, identify site specific issues, and link them to information obtained from other methods of urban design site analysis. (What is the story of your data?)

• identify important participants in Twitter and Facebook conversations and topics of interest (i.e. what are people talking about??)

Use theoretical concepts from the lectures and readings, or as agreed with your tutor, to frame, interpret, and explain the findings from your visual observation of the public realm site as well as—and compared with—your ‘digital’ observation of the 

public realm site through social media data analysis. TASK 1 & 2 DELIVERABLES:

• a dynamic and mixed digital media presentation with a verbal presentation of 10minutes (maximum) per group

• social media data analysis graphs and visualisations

TASK 3: ESSAY INDIVIDUAL (15%)

Individually each student will write and submit a 1000word (minimum) essay that reflects on the socio-digital life of the urban space you have researched. This essay MUST frame the observations / findings through a theoretical lens (or range of theoretical concepts from the lectures and readings or as agreed with your tutor, to interpret and explain your observations). This essay MUST adhere to the UNSW academic referencing system - Harvard In-text Style.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"63905d57dba93850be4672f5f3961921","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"6b905d57dba93850be4672f5f3961920","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"6b905d57dba93850be4672f5f3961921","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"6f905d57dba93850be4672f5f3961926","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assignment 1: Position – Technology manifesto (Individual)","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"20","description":"

Recalling the concepts, ideas, and communication techniques, aesthetic, and vigour of the 1960s art and architectural avant-garde as presented in the lectures and further researched independently, students will design a visual technology manifesto using a range of media, including a combination of text, key words, images, diagrams, static and/or dynamic, (and/or 3D elements) to communicate their own ideas about the present and future relationships between technology(s), design practice, people, and the built environment. Presentation size and format to be discussed and agreed in tutorial with your tutor, minimum CONTENT to fill A1 – but NOT arranged as an A1 layout – be creative, explore how the graphic layout can express the themes and ideas you intend to communicate. The presentation must be accompanied by a 500w (minimum) manifesto statement.

contentlets.keywords: digital architecture,urban theory and ubiquitous cities,cyborg theory,contemporary design theory,digital humanities,philosophy of technology
contentlets.description: 'The Computational Design Theory II course builds on the foundational knowledge of CODE1110 – Computational Design Theory I, that introduced students to computational thinking and methods in the context of the architectural discipline and practice, to investigate historic and contemporary approaches to representing, conceptualising, and designing the built environment in relationship to digital culture and computing technologies. Students will develop and apply advanced critical thinking skills to analyse relationships between digital culture and the built environment and apply conceptual and theoretical ideas to interpret and explain their findings. This course explores and advances the ethical application of digital and computational technologies to inform the student’s own design practice.
contentlets.title: Computational Design Theory 2

course."}],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"CODE1231 - Ubiquitous Cities","description":"

'This course introduces and critiques discourses, policies, and case examples of regional and global digital, ubiquitous, and smart city thinking and initiatives. This knowledge further informs an exploration of the application of computational thinking and methods to urban and spatial analysis, and the creation of design projects that adopt principles of physical computing, interaction design and human-machine interaction. The course culminates in the creation, construction, and presentation of interaction design proposals and working interaction design prototypes that engage sensing and actuating technologies.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"a8a09d57dba93850be4672f5f396195f","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assignment 2: Urban Interaction Design Research (individual)","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"30","description":"

Students will be allocated a specific precinct within the TBC to examine and analyse for design issues and opportunities. Assignment 2 and undertake two key tasks: 1) Precinct site analysis to inform a problem definition framework; 2) Digital placemaking/interaction design precedent research.

TASK 1: The TBC precinct analysis should communicate information that defines the precinct (physically, socially, conceptually) in the form of photos, video, diagrams, drawings (plans, sections, elevations, 3D model) or other to address various questions. From this analysis, and with consideration of course readings, construct/design a ‘problem definition framework’, that identifies a series of ‘problems’ to be solved, or issues and opportunities to be addressed, to inform a design brief for Assignment 3.

TASK 2: Drawing on the analysis and reflecting on the role(s) ‘smart’ technologies can play in addressing the issues/opportunities identified identify minimum x4 precedent examples of urban interaction design projects (existing or speculative) and outline their relevance and applicability to your public realm site.

 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"e4a09d57dba93850be4672f5f3961960","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"eca09d57dba93850be4672f5f3961960","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"38a09d57dba93850be4672f5f3961970","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assignment 1: Smart Cities initiatives case study (20%) and Comparative Analysis (10%) (Individual)","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"30","description":"

TASK 1 SMART CITY CASE STUDY (20% / Week 3)

Smart city case study (20%) During the first tutorial students will undertake preliminary research and select a ‘smart city’ case example (speculative and/or implemented). Students are required to undertake detailed case study research about their chosen smart city through a range of resources including scholarly material such as journal articles and book chapters, as well as other 

resources such as commercial (business) and institutional (i.e. local government) publications. The 500-750word case study should outline details of the smart city/region including location, population, and any other relevant statistics/facts. The writing should outline why the case example is considered to constitute a ‘smart city’, i.e. in what ways does it align to academic definitions of a ‘smart city’, and/or who promotes it as a ‘smart city’? Further information should address when the case study smart city strategy was developed, and what ‘smart’ initiatives, strategies, or designs that it advances? What sort of hard and soft technologies does the case example discuss and prioritise? Who organises, implements and manages these initiatives? How have the objectives of the case study smart city proposal been realised and put into action? What can be said about any of the outcomes and resulting quality of urban life? In what ways has the initiative developed and changed over time? The written and graphic presentation is required to situate the smart city case study within the broader paradigm of smart city discourse. From this perspective, the written text should be expository; it should make an argument about the efficacy and/or fallacy of ‘smart’ city rhetoric, policy, planning, and design issues.

TASK 2: COMPARATIVE ANALYSIS (10% / WEEK 4)

Students are required to write a 500word (minimum) comparative analysis that compares the initiatives of their own smart city case example with one other smart city case example presented by another student. Students will be allocated a comparative smart city prior to the presentation. 

 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"e4a09d57dba93850be4672f5f3961960","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"eca09d57dba93850be4672f5f3961960","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"68a09d57dba93850be4672f5f3961963","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Online Exam: Moodle Quiz","assessment_type":{"label":"Test","value":"test"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"10","description":"

Multiple choice questions based on material presented in lectures and tutorial readings.

 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"eca09d57dba93850be4672f5f3961960","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"70a09d57dba93850be4672f5f396196e","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Urban Interaction Design (Group)","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"30","description":"

In groups students will design and prototype an urban interaction design project for their allocated public realm site. This will include writing a conceptual statement of 250 words (minimum) that outlines how the proposed project addresses the refined problem definition framework (see Assignment 2). For example, the analysis may have emphasised a community or social issue, or contextual condition (such as environmental awareness, historical interpretation, or a site-specific issue such as a safety or a pedestrian optimisation strategy) This design should innovatively propose ways to enhance and activate the public realm (or even reinterpret/reinvigorate not-sopublic areas) and engage users through the designed synthesis of material (physical components) and immaterial (informational) conditions. The project MUST propose ways to sense and collect relevant data and ‘meaningfully’ respond to it, in other words, it must integrate interactive real-time content – such as light/visualisations (LEDs / projection), sound, pressure, and/or movement, through applying skills learned in the Arduino workshops, and lectures, and utilising various data and sensing collection methods and electronic technologies (actuators, sensors, detectors etc). The project MUST outline ways the ‘data’ from sensing and actuating technologies can be fed-back into the interactive system or potentially other institutional/city systems in ethical ways.

In this course students will critique discourse, policies, case studies of regional and global computational urbanism and apply computational thinking and methods including a wide range of geospatial data, formats, and modelling to analyse urban sites. At the end of the course students will be able to create digital tools and workflows for the management of urban data by applying proficient skills in programming to address interoperability challenges for urban data management.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"bcb01597dba93850be4672f5f39619b8","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Urban Data","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"40","description":"

Assessment type:

Report & presentation.

Investigate and identify suitable data sets that can assist with completing tasks in urban design [individual work].

Analyze the workflow of urban design and identify and position ‘tasks’ towards generating urban design in a workflow [individual work].


 

Feedback process:

Peer critique and one to one consultation.

Assessment type:

Design presentation

Using a block-chain using, two-sided network platform students will apply the automated tasks towards designing with urban data  (building envelop) for a precinct.


 

Feedback process:

Peer critique and one to one consultation.

course."}],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"CODE1240 - Computational Design 2 (Intermediate)","description":"

'Computational Design II (Intermediate)' is the second of four Computational Design courses that introduce students to Computational Design. Students will develop and apply intermediate skills in visual programming languages to critically analyse complex environmental conditions, while synthesising computational design thinking knowledge and methods for solving built environment challenges. Theoretical knowledge will be introduced falling under the following categories: Morphology, Algorithmic Form, Emergence, and Systems. Students will participate to weekly laboratory-based activities to experiment with and develop architectural forms. The students performance will be evaluated with respect to their progressive work developed in preparation for or during the studio activities. Students will employ a range of verbal and multimedia communication skills to demonstrate their explorations and results.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"39b05597dba93850be4672f5f39619b5","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Project Development","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"40","description":"

You will develop a parametric design tool (script) to create a flexible/adaptable solution for your design brief. Represent in a sketch the main steps, and the parameters that will allow to modify the design regarding to spatial performance. You will prepare a mixed-media presentation to demonstrate in class how the parametric tool works. You will submit a poster that documents the project.

Verbal feedback will be given during the presentation in class and a feedback sheet will be given in Moodle that indicates the level of achievement against the assessment criteria rubric as well as a section for additional comments.

 

 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"b1b05597dba93850be4672f5f39619b7","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"b1b05597dba93850be4672f5f39619b8","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"b9b05597dba93850be4672f5f39619b6","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"b9b05597dba93850be4672f5f39619b7","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"79b05597dba93850be4672f5f39619b9","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Design Thinking","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"20","description":"

You will conduct research about a global challenge and work together with a client or client group. By interviewing a representative of the client group, you will collect information to define the design brief, and understand user needs and the local context including available resources in the area. You will create a mixed-media presentation and present the research in class, including your design brief, and initial sketches proposals.

Verbal feedback will be given during the presentation in class and a feedback sheet will be given in Moodle that indicates the level of achievement against the assessment criteria rubric as well as a section for additional comments.

n the final assessment, you will develop a script to optimize your design, improving its efficiency and performance in relation to the environmental conditions of the area. You will prepare a mixed-media presentation to demonstrate in class how the parametric tool works. You will submit a poster that documents the project.

Verbal feedback will be given during the presentation in class and a feedback sheet will be given in Moodle that indicates the level of achievement against the assessment criteria rubric as well as a section for additional comments

contentlets.description: 'Computational Design II (Intermediate)' is the second of four Computational Design courses that introduce students to Computational Design. Students will develop and apply intermediate skills in visual programming languages to critically analyse complex environmental conditions, while synthesising computational design thinking knowledge and methods for solving built environment challenges. Theoretical knowledge will be introduced falling under the following categories: Morphology, Algorithmic Form, Emergence, and Systems. Students will participate to weekly laboratory-based activities to experiment with and develop architectural forms. The students performance will be evaluated with respect to their progressive work developed in preparation for or during the studio activities. Students will employ a range of verbal and multimedia communication skills to demonstrate their explorations and results.
contentlets.title: Computational Design 2 (Intermediate)

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"CODE2120 - Building Data","description":"

In this course students will critique discourse, policies, case studies of computational methods and tools used for optimisation as well as decision-support in architecture and engineering disciplines. They will also gain skills in applying computational thinking and methods to building information data, formats, and modelling to address optimisation and decision-support in the architecture and engineering disciplines. Consequently students will apply proficient skills in programming to address interoperability challenges for building data management in order to create digital tools and workflows for the management of building data.

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"CODE2121 - Computational Design 3 (Advanced)","description":"

'Computational Design III (Advanced) is the third of four Computational Design courses that introduce students to Computational Design. Students will investigate, develop and apply computational thinking and methods in the context of the engineering discipline and practice, to analyse, evaluate and generate a structurally sound design. Students will participate to weekly laboratory-based activities to simulate, analyse, evaluate and design structurally performing architecture. The students performance will be evaluated with respect to their progressive work developed in preparation for or during the studio activities. Students will employ a range of verbal and multimedia communication skills to demonstrate their explorations and results.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"e5c09997dba93850be4672f5f39619c9","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assignment 1: Structural Foundations","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"15","description":"

For the first 5 weeks we have a lecture series from a Structural Engineer. Coupled with these lectures are a series of tutorial exercises which involve constructing and testing small structures. The lectures and exercises will be recorded in a report, due Week 3. This report

requirements are: A4, PDF document, 2x minimum pages dedicated to each model made in class 2x minimum page appendix of at least 1 page. Each model needs to be photographed and analysed for this report, and students are required to create a Grasshopper script representing the physical model.

 

Peer critique from tutors

 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"21c09997dba93850be4672f5f39619cc","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"29c09997dba93850be4672f5f39619cb","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"65c09997dba93850be4672f5f39619d4","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assignment 2: Karamba","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"35","description":"

The second assignment requires students to use their new skills attained through the lectures and a Karamba workshop to design a pavilion.

This assignment uses the first assignment as base to work from. Students will be required to test their original models in a digital environment and design improvements. An amended report is required at the end: 2x minimum extra pages per model, describing Karamba analysis and improvements

The lecture series will continue through this assignment, and students will be required to submit an appended appendix from their first assignment. Additionally to this, the students are required to combine collected knowledge

from the lecture series, along with new skills in Karamba, to design a small pavilion for a bar. Brief details and requirements will be introduced at the beginning of the assignment. The pavilion will become the final structure in the report, requiring a minimum of 4x pages, which will included plans, sections

and perspective/isometric renders.

 

Peer critique from tutors

 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"21c09997dba93850be4672f5f39619cc","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"21c09997dba93850be4672f5f39619cd","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"29c09997dba93850be4672f5f39619cb","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"29c09997dba93850be4672f5f39619cc","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"e5c09997dba93850be4672f5f39619ce","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assignment 3: Stadium","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"50","description":"

The final project requires the students to use their new found knowledge from Assignment 1 and 2, but with real world/industry based design restrictions; a stadium structure. Students are required to create a developed, evocative design that also demonstrates their knowledge in structures.

 

Peer critique from tutors

In this course, students will apply proficient skills in a visual programming language interface and advanced skills in a text based programming language. Through these skills they can create, analyse and evaluate mathematical algorithms for data driven design. The outcomes demonstrate skills in collaborative work practices by applying computational design knowledge and skills. In addition, by applying relevant verbal and multimedia communication skills, students will present their work to an academic / industry panel. 


 

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"79d051d7dba93850be4672f5f3961926","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"3. Evaluating and implementing and Students’ Research Report","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"30","description":"

In this last assignment students will present final developments in their design project and demonstrate how boundaries of disciplinary understanding could be challenged. The final design will be presented in front of a panel.

\n

The report will conclude and document your findings in CODE2132 by providing clarity and meticulousness in delivering and communicating content’s information    

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"39d051d7dba93850be4672f5f3961927","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"39d051d7dba93850be4672f5f3961928","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"0ed051d7dba93850be4672f5f3961932","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"1.Understanding of complex systems and Investigation of self-organisation algorithm","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"30","description":"

Students are asked to investigate and challenge the boundaries of their disciplinary understanding for designing a cointegration between biomimicry, architecture and computational neuroscience. Through a presentation students will showcase their investigation of self-organising algorithm which will function as a foundation for generating a biometric solution for a complex system.

Using the knowledge gained in assignment 1 students will make use of mathematical principles and theories accurately, abstracting and applying them in novel situations to design a project.

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"CODE2170 - Building Information Modelling","description":"

This Building Information Modelling (BIM) course introduces you to identify and explain the concepts and methods of BIM information management, BIM standards, and BIM in the architectural and urban design. You will investigate and explain high-performance building design through BIM and BIM-enabled design analysis, while applying advanced skills in BIM for the design, documentation and visualisation of buildings. You will collaborate in multi-disciplinary teams to achieve optimal design solutions, and your performance will be evaluated with respect to your progressive work developed in preparation for or during the tutorial activities. 

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"f2d091d7dba93850be4672f5f3961935","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":"Group","value":"Group"},"assessment_name":"Assignment 2 - Advanced BIM Project","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"50","description":"

Group Model/Documentation (20%), Individual Model/Documentation (20%), and Collaboration – Project activity log data on Cloud (10%).

\n

You will develop collaborative BIM skills through the second assignment. Each community complex has its own consistent design concept and/or a scenario for the complex design, and two to four social functions (depending on your group size).

\n

Each complex design has a group design model (20%) that connects to individual models (20%). In addition, your collaborative activities (10%) are automatically recorded through a cloud-based BIM platform like BIM360.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"32d091d7dba93850be4672f5f3961937","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"3ad091d7dba93850be4672f5f3961936","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"3ad091d7dba93850be4672f5f3961937","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"b6d091d7dba93850be4672f5f3961940","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Quiz","assessment_type":{"label":"Examination","value":"examination"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"10","description":"

Two quizzes, each of which consists of 10 multiple choice questions, will be taken to test your knowledge about BIM and BIM practice.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"32d091d7dba93850be4672f5f3961936","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"f2d091d7dba93850be4672f5f3961939","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Assignment 1 - Basic BIM Project","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"40","description":"

You will learn BIM and its essential visualisation and documentation through intellectual explorations into a simple design/modelling assignment like housing design.

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"CODE2230 - Human Machine Interaction","description":"

This course is part of the practice orientated teaching trajectory ‘Contextualising’ combining Stream 3: Smart and Ubiquitous Cities and Stream 4: Responsive Environments. The course will introduce students to urban interaction design by teaching principles of human-machine interaction in the built environment, together with movement planning and electronics.


This course will provide students with the conceptual understanding, technical skills and working methods needed to design a computer-mediated project that effectively explores a compelling interactive spatial solution. Using low-cost open-source electronic hardware (Arduino or Little Bits Kits), students will learn how to implement techniques to test and develop working design prototypes and situate these into the built environment. Theories and project themes will be developed around the two stream interests Stream 3: Smart and Ubiquitous Cities and Stream 4: Responsive Environments, with a specific focus on facilitating natural and effective modes of interaction with robotic technologies in the built environment.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"31f01dd7dba93850be4672f5f39619a6","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"2: RESOLVED MECHANISM PROTOTYPE (Marked Individually)","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"40","description":"

This aim of this task is to foster curatorial skills in the iterative design process and to build student skills in the fabrication and resolution of a 1:1 prototype for real-world application.

Of the three mechanism prototypes developed in Task 1B, choose one and build a functional and finished prototype of this mechanism. The mechanism should operate as autonomously as possible, and options for actuation should be discussed with your lecturer. The fabrication of this mechanism should be in the materiality and to the resolution of that envisaged for the final pavilion.

Note: Each member of the group must speak during the presentation and make clear their contribution to project. Students must demonstrate their on-going active engagement throughout this task and will be given individual grades.

*Group assignment marked individually.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"31f01dd7dba93850be4672f5f39619a7","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"31f01dd7dba93850be4672f5f39619a8","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"39f01dd7dba93850be4672f5f39619a6","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"39f01dd7dba93850be4672f5f39619a7","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"3df01dd7dba93850be4672f5f39619b2","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"1B: MECHANISM PROTOTYPES (Marked Individually)","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"40","description":"

The aim of this task is for students to focus on articulating thoughtful, high-quality, optimized movement, and to explore and fabricate a range of design solutions, through iteration, for a given design scenario.

Fabricate 3 x 1:1 prototypes of different movement mechanisms that could be implemented in the Centaur Pod pavilion. These prototypes can be built from place-holder prototyping materials, but the movement of the mechanism must be highly resolved.

*Group assignment marked individually.

 

 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"31f01dd7dba93850be4672f5f39619a7","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"39f01dd7dba93850be4672f5f39619a6","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"39f01dd7dba93850be4672f5f39619a7","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"f1f01dd7dba93850be4672f5f39619ae","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"1A: MOVEMENT PLANNING (Marked Individually)","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"20","description":"

This task is designed to encourage students to investigate different kinds of movement mechanisms, to understand how they operate and apply various design possibilities to a given scenario to optimize movement.

In groups, compose 3 short animations (less than 1 min each) that demonstrate three different movement mechanisms and how each of these mechanisms might be implemented in the Centaur Pod pavilion. Animations may be made in any program, and the files or link to the files hosted online must be submitted on Moodle, by the due date.

The animations will be presented in a 15 min presentation in class. Each group should take 5 mins to discuss each mechanism, show the animation, and describe the advantages and challenges of implementing each. Each mechanism should be discussed in relation to the interaction theories and principles described in the lectures and readings for optimized movement and affective interaction.

Note: Each member of the group must speak during the presentation and make clear their contribution to the research and composition of the animations. Students must demonstrate their on-going active engagement throughout this task and will be given individual grades.

*Group assignment marked individually.

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"CODE2250 - Advanced Digital Fabrication","description":"

The course introduces and critiques innovative research studies on digital fabrication techniques and technologies. Students will be provided with the conceptual understanding, technical skills and working methods required to fabricate a responsive spatial solution, and apply principles of robotics and digital fabrication. The students performance will be evaluated with respect to their progressive work developed in preparation for or during the studio activities. Students will employ a range of verbal and multimedia communication skills to represent and deliver their research approach and prototyping results with professionalism, clarity and purpose.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"7af05dd7dba93850be4672f5f39619e4","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Design Proposal and Material Exploration","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"30","description":"

a.: Literature review presentations; Origami pattern and pavilion proposals; GH script of the unfolded pattern; Prototypes in paper, cardboard and polypropylene.
b.: Simulation of a rigid and flexible skin using Kangaroo.
c.: Simulation of the skin using rigid plates in Kangaroo, Influence of the material thickness in the design, Clash detection and tolerances; Kinetic skin prototypes, Single digital fabrication Technique and Material, Iteration I; Details of Connections for the upscale model.
d: Simulation of the skin using flexible and inflatable plates in Kangaroo; Kinetic Skin Prototypes, Single Digital Fabrication Technique and Material, Iteration II; Details of connections for the upscale model.
e.: Rethinking the kinetic skin; Combination of digital fabrication techniques and materials; Connections and joints; Digital model for fabrication; Final prototype.
f.: Work in progress research report and Presentation; Movement simulation of the model. 

 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"72f05dd7dba93850be4672f5f39619e5","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"72f05dd7dba93850be4672f5f39619e6","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"72f05dd7dba93850be4672f5f39619e7","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"7af05dd7dba93850be4672f5f39619e5","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"7af05dd7dba93850be4672f5f39619e6","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"8ff05dd7dba93850be4672f5f39619f5","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Structural Analysis and Model for Fabrication","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"30","description":"

a.: The Skeleton: design and structural Analysis using Karamba; Adaptation of the skin to the grid shell, contact points, clash detection, new adapted pattern; Wireframe digital model; Pavilion prototype: 3D printed skeleton + paper skin.
b.: The skeleton as a modular system, design of elements, parts and joints; Digital model for fabrication (skeleton, skin and connection elements); Prototype of the skeleton for structural load test.

a.: Mock-up of the skeleton CLO.
b.: Mock-up of the skin CLO.
c.: Final research report and presentation.

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"CODE2270 - Design Information Management","description":"

The course introduces and critiques building information standards, policies and applications. Students will be provided with the conceptual understanding, technical skills and working methods required to communicate and collaborate via Building Information Models, and apply principles of building information management, communication and specification. The students performance will be evaluated with respect to their progressive work developed in preparation for or during the studio activities. Students will employ a range of verbal and multimedia communication skills to represent and deliver their research approach and management documentation with professionalism, clarity and purpose.

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"CODE3100 - Digital Collaboration Studio","description":"

'The Digital Collaboration Studio is the graduation year opening course of the Bachelor of Computational Design degree. The course introduces students to the design of bioinspired kinetic environments. Students adopt an action research approach, characterised by the iterative progression between the conceptualisation of a problem, the action towards its resolution, and the evaluation of that action, to generate a responsive design solution in the form of a small-scale pavilion. Students are exposed to the mathematical, physical and environmental principles necessary to simulate and evaluate changes to the pavilion's kinetic structure, material system and overall shape. The course culminates in the authorship of a machine learning algorithm predicting the morphing behaviour of the pavilion, and with a physical prototype of the pavilion's kinetic material system.

The Graduation Project is the culmination of the Computational Design studios and the Bachelor of Computational Design degree. It develops a written component (thesis) in CODE3201 that is underpinned through project / practice work in CODE3202. Both CODE3201 and CODE3202 are one package and students need to be enrolled in both. Graduation Projects will take research findings and knowledge gained in Semester 1 (CODE3100) and deepen and extend this knowledge in CODE3201. In order to assess their skills and monitor the progress of their thesis CODE3201 has following key objectives. Students will produce as a final thesis outcome a 4 - 6000 word report in form of a conference paper style submission describing and discussing their project. The research project context is defined by preliminary research done in Semester 1 and presented and confirmed at the final presentation in CODE3100. The thesis outline in detail: (1) Research aims and motivation; (2) Research Objectives; (3) Research Question; (4) Methodology to answer question; (5) Background Research; (6) Case study or the specific project students worked on; (7) Significance of Research by position it to the work by others (Test cases); (8) Evaluation of work; and (9) Conclusion.  Teaching in CODE3201 is done via a one-to-one supervision and thesis and project must fit within one of the seven paths and give students the chance to specialize in one of the paths as part of their degree and consequently gaining a proficiency level in the subject. We apply Design Research as a methodological structure for both, CODE3201 and CODE3202 as:"Design Research is a systematic search for and acquisition of knowledge related to general human ecology, considered from a 'designerly way of thinking (i.e., project-oriented) perspective." (Findeli, 2010)

contentlets.description: The Graduation Project is the culmination of the Computational Design studios and the Bachelor of Computational Design degree. It develops a written component (thesis) in CODE3201 that is underpinned through project / practice work in CODE3202. Both CODE3201 and CODE3202 are one package and students need to be enrolled in both. Graduation Projects will take research findings and knowledge gained in Semester 1 (CODE3100) and deepen and extend this knowledge in CODE3201. In order to assess their skills and monitor the progress of their thesis CODE3201 has following key objectives. Students will produce as a final thesis outcome a 4 - 6000 word report in form of a conference paper style submission describing and discussing their project. The research project context is defined by preliminary research done in Semester 1 and presented and confirmed at the final presentation in CODE3100. The thesis outline in detail: (1) Research aims and motivation; (2) Research Objectives; (3) Research Question; (4) Methodology to answer question; (5) Background Research; (6) Case study or the specific project students worked on; (7) Significance of Research by position it to the work by others (Test cases); (8) Evaluation of work; and (9) Conclusion.  Teaching in CODE3201 is done via a one-to-one supervision and thesis and project must fit within one of the seven paths and give students the chance to specialize in one of the paths as part of their degree and consequently gaining a proficiency level in the subject. Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"CODE3202 - Graduation Project: Practice","description":"

'The Graduation Project is the culmination of the Computational Design studios and the Bachelor of Computational Design degree. CODE3201 and CODE3202 are one package and students must be enrolled in both courses. CODE3202 develops rigorous testing and systematic skills for developing a research informed solution within the context of a practice-based computational design project. This is aligned with the Computational Design degree overarching goal to prepare students by developing research knowledge and reflective practice, and exposing them to the theoretical and practical principles associated with a research informed approach. Students will be either partnered with an industry-based supevisor to design a solution for a "real-world" problem, or will be requested to develop an independent research question. The course culminates in the authorship of a physical or digital prototype, that reflects a critical thinking as well as a systematic and professional research approach.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"0301911bdba93850be4672f5f39619b6","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assignment 2 (Design Iterations)","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"50","description":"

(Design Iteration I in Week 6 / 20%) In each iterative design process one will showcase and present iterations that lead towards the final design. The first iteration naturally takes on board a lot of the research findings students have gained in CODE3201. Hence students need to demonstrate that they are able to transfer knowledge gained in CODE3201 into CODE3202.

(Design Iteration II in Week 10 / 20%) The second iteration naturally builds upon the first and at this stage each student should be in a position to present and demonstrate either working prototypes, software that runs at least in parts or shows a completion status larger then 60% based on the design objectives stated in Assignment 1.

(Design Iteration III in Week 13 / 20%) Your Design should be completed by now! The design iteration process needs to be wrapped up in Week 13 and you will be evaluated and marked on if you meet your objectives and the originality and rigour of the design outcome. The week 13 presentation will give you the go ahead to document your already completed design, i.e. do the final edit of the video, or prepare and develop the diagrams (See Design objective exemplar above).

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"8701911bdba93850be4672f5f39619b9","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"8f01911bdba93850be4672f5f39619b7","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"8f01911bdba93850be4672f5f39619b8","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"8f01911bdba93850be4672f5f39619b9","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"4701911bdba93850be4672f5f39619bb","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assignment 1 (Design Objectives)","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"20","description":"

As each thesis project will differ from the other one each student is required to set the objectives for ones project. The objectives will state what will be delivered at the end of the semester in the graduation presentation. This could be i.e. three prototypes, a software that can do ‘X’ or ‘Y’ and so on. The objectives should be carefully discussed with the tutors and the potential industry partners in order to assure that the work is not to extensive for a Bachelor thesis (and at the same time the opposite does not cover the level and the extend of a Bachelor thesis) and should meet the requirements and expectations of the industry partners.

 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"8701911bdba93850be4672f5f39619b8","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"8701911bdba93850be4672f5f39619b9","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"8f01911bdba93850be4672f5f39619b8","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"8f01911bdba93850be4672f5f39619b9","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"4f01911bdba93850be4672f5f39619c6","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assignment 3 (Design Documentation and Graduation Presentation)","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"30","description":"

(Sketch Book  in Week 13 / 10%) Your ‘Sketch book’ has demonstrated during the semester what has happened what ideas you had what directions you took in your design and where you started and stopped to potentially try different routes. A sketch book does not necessarily have to be an analogue sketch book (paper based) but can be also a blog you set up for your Graduation Studio (CODE3201 and CODE3202)   

(Graduation Presentation in week 15 / 20%) With your design finished CODE3201 and CODE3202 are now morphed closer together. What ever you have been designing in CODE3202 has been documented and outlined as the ‘Project’ section of your thesis in CODE3201. Still we would like to see the work you have done in CODE3202 as well in the combined Graduand Thesis presentation. The Final Presentation is in Week 15 at the exhibition location at a gallery in front of a panel compromising academics (all staff CoDe), academics, industry partners and the public. At this event each student has 15 min with 5 min question to explain and present their graduation project to a panel. An evening event will conclude the semester for students and staff and celebrates the graduation with friends and family.

CODE3202 develops rigorous testing and systematic skills for developing a research informed solution within the context of a practice-based computational design project. This is aligned with the Computational Design degree overarching goal to prepare students by developing research knowledge and reflective practice, and exposing them to the theoretical and practical principles associated with a research informed approach. Students will be either partnered with an industry-based supevisor to design a solution for a "real-world" problem, or will be requested to develop an independent research question. The course culminates in the authorship of a physical or digital prototype, that reflects a critical thinking as well as a systematic and professional research approach.
contentlets.title: Graduation Project: Practice

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"CODE4100 - Critical Review of the Literature","description":"

This course is a major research-based investigation into a subject related to the student’s area of specialisation. It can be seen as a building block for ARCH 1482 and CODE4200, but it is a standalone project and yields its own outcome – a critical review of the computational design literature. This leads to a culmination of a well-informed understanding of the chosen research topic. It is expected that the critical review of the literature will offer a critical interpretation of the existing knowledge and literature. The length of the final as submitted literature review, should not exceed 8,000 words. 

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"c811151bdba93850be4672f5f3961937","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Panel review","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"10","description":"

The panel review is designed to provide an opportunity to clearly and succinctly explain the research question, it’s background and the supporting literature to a small group of staff, fellow students, and others It recognizes importance of peer feedback for the critical review of the literature as a whole.


Peer Review and critique    

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"0011151bdba93850be4672f5f3961939","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"0011151bdba93850be4672f5f396193a","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"0811151bdba93850be4672f5f3961938","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"0811151bdba93850be4672f5f3961939","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"0c11151bdba93850be4672f5f396195e","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Annotated Bibliography","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"10","description":"

Demonstrates information literacy - the skills to appropriately locate, evaluate and use relevant information; a respect for ethical practice and social responsibility; the skills of effective communication. All students will demonstrate mastery of a recognised bibliographic citation system.

\n

Approximately 1000 words with at least 20 scholarly texts


Review by course-coordinator and students thesis supervisor    

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"0011151bdba93850be4672f5f396193a","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"0811151bdba93850be4672f5f3961939","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"8011151bdba93850be4672f5f396193b","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Critical review of selected texts","assessment_type":{"label":"Essay","value":"essay"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"20","description":"

Demonstrates evidence that the student can evaluate the literature for what it contributes to the field of knowledge, and for its relevance to their research question. 20,000 word thesis.


Review by course-coordinator and students thesis supervisor  

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"0011151bdba93850be4672f5f396193a","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"0811151bdba93850be4672f5f3961938","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"8811151bdba93850be4672f5f3961957","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Integrated Critical Review","assessment_type":{"label":"Essay","value":"essay"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"60","description":"

This is a comprehensive Critical Review of the Literature, that draws on scholarly literature, relevant to the students research question, it also includes a critique of the relevant literature on the selected research methods.

\n

It involves analysis + synthesis. 7,000 words, plus the composite bibliography.


Review by course-coordinator and students thesis supervisor    

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"0011151bdba93850be4672f5f3961939","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"0811151bdba93850be4672f5f3961938","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"c011151bdba93850be4672f5f396195b","links":[]}]}],"inactive_course_alert":null,"timetableURL":"http://timetable.unsw.edu.au/2022/CODE4100.html","subject_sample_text_staticcontent":"To access course outline, please visit:","links":[]}

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"CODE4200 - Honours Thesis","description":"

This course is a major research-based investigation into a subject related to the student’s area of specialisation. It can be seen as a building block for ARCH 1482 and CODE4200, but it is a standalone project and yields its own outcome – a critical review of the computational design literature. This leads to a culmination of a well-informed understanding of the chosen research topic. It is expected that the critical review of the literature will offer a critical interpretation of the existing knowledge and literature. The length of the thesis, including drawings, models and illustrations, should not exceed 20,000 words.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"2811551bdba93850be4672f5f396191b","name":"Independent research - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Final Thesis","assessment_type":{"label":"Essay","value":"essay"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"70","description":"

A coherent piece of research grounded in relevant theory and literature that clearly: defines the scope of the research, demonstrates a mastery of the field via a critical analysis of the literature, locates key data resources, analyse the various data sets, correlates/synthesises the various findings, evaluates the entire project for its contribution to the field, and is written in clear and succinct style. Bibliographic referencing is accurate and appropriate i.e. a UNSW recognised system such as Chicago, APA, or Harvard is used.    


Thesis examination (2 examiners unassociated with teaching and supervision)

To the critical review of the literature, you will add your results, discussion and conclusion chapters. In doing so it is important to identifying theoretical patterns within your field - perhaps driven by different authors’ disciplinary, geographic, ideological, or temporal biases. Different scholars, reading the same material, may legitimately come to different conclusions about its characteristics and significance; each, after all, may have a different interest and purpose. Therefore, having identified the patterns in the field, your task is to provide a cogent interpretation. You might ask: what are the core characteristics of an identified particular pattern within the field? How useful are they to my area of research? Think about evidence – internal to some of the articles, and external, as provided by other sources of knowledge – you would use to persuade a reader to accept your interpretation. 20,000 word thesis.    


Structured feedback from thesis supervisor.
